Functions

int son_get_error (son_t *h)
 
The path to the file to create

This function creates a new SON file.

When you create an SON file, you specify the name where the file will be created. If the file already exists, it is overwritten.

You also need to provide a stack. This is so the library can work without using dynamic memory allocation. The stack_size needs to be as large as the deepest depth of the data. For example, the following JSON data has a depth of 3.

{
"make": { //depth level 1 (all files have a depth of at least 1)
"model" : { //depth level 2
"color" : "red" //depth level 3
}
}
}
Parameters
hA pointer to the SON handle
stackA pointer to the SON stack structure
stack_sizeThe number of stack entries available in the stack

Macro Definition Documentation

#define SON_ACCESS_MAX_USER_SIZE

This defines the maximum length of the user supplied values for the access parameter.

#define SON_KEY_NAME_SIZE

This defines the maximum length of any given key value.

Typedef Documentation

typedef u32 son_size_t

SON Size Type

Enumeration Type Documentation

anonymous enum

These values are assigned to son_t->err when an operation does not complete successfully.

Enumerator
SON_ERR_NONE 

This value indicates no error has occurred.

SON_ERR_NO_ROOT 

This error happens when a top level object or array is not created.

SON_ERR_OPEN_IO 

This error happens if there is an IO failure to create or open a file (run perror() for more info).

SON_ERR_READ_IO 

This error happens when an IO read operation fails (run perror() for more info).

SON_ERR_WRITE_IO 

This error happens when an IO write operation fails (run perror() for more info).

SON_ERR_CLOSE_IO 

This error happens when an IO close operation fails (run perror() for more info).

SON_ERR_SEEK_IO 

This error happens when an IO seek operation fails (run perror() for more info).

SON_ERR_READ_CHECKSUM 

This error happens when the data in the file has a invalid checksum which indicates a corrupted file or bad file format.

SON_ERR_CANNOT_APPEND 

This error happens when an append is attempted on a file that has not been saved for appending

SON_ERR_CANNOT_WRITE 

This error happens if a write is attempted on a file that has been opened for reading

SON_ERR_CANNOT_READ 

This error happens if a read is attempted on a file that has been opened for writing or appending

SON_ERR_INVALID_ROOT 

This error happens when the root object is not valid (usually a bad file format or corrupted file).

SON_ERR_ARRAY_INDEX_NOT_FOUND 

This error happens when an array index could not be found

SON_ERR_ACCESS_TOO_LONG 

This error happens if the access parameter len exceeds SON_ACCESS_MAX_USER_SIZE.

SON_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND 

This error happens when the key specified by the access parameter could not be found.

SON_ERR_STACK_OVERFLOW 

This error happens if the depth (son_open_array() or son_open_obj()) exceeds, the handle's stack size.

SON_ERR_INVALID_KEY 

This happens if an empty key is passed to anything but the root object.

SON_ERR_CANNOT_CONVERT 

This happens if a read is tried by the base data can't be converted

SON_ERR_EDIT_TYPE_MISMATCH 

This happens if a value is edited with a function that doesn't match the base type

Function Documentation

int son_append ( son_t *  h,
const char *  name,
son_stack_t *  stack,
size_t  stack_size 
)

This function will open a SON file for appending. Items written to the file will be added to the root object or array.

1 son_stack_t son_stack[10];
2 son_t son;
3 son_append(&son, "/home/append.son", son_stack, 10);
4 son_write_str(&son, "str", "World"); //this will be appended to "array" and accessed at "array[1]".
5 son_close(&son, 1); //close out all structures -- no more appending
int son_close ( son_t *  h)

This function closes a file that has been opened with either son_create(), son_append(), or son_open().

Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
Returns
Less than zero (perror() for details)

See also

Returns
Less than zero on error

Close an object while creating or appending a SON file.

int son_edit ( son_t *  h,
const char *  name 
)

Opens a file for editing.

For variable length data types (SON_DATA and SON_STRING), the data can be modified but the size of the data is fixed. Writing a string that is shorter will work as expected. Writing a string (or data chunk) that is larger than the original will trucate data that doesn't fit.

When a value is edited, the value type must match the function used to edit the value (no conversion is performed). An error (SON_ERR_EDIT_TYPE_MISMATCH) will be set if this is attempted.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
nameThe name of the file to open
Returns
Less than zero for an error

int son_get_error ( son_t *  h)

Returns the most recent error and sets the current error value to SON_ERR_NONE.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
int son_open ( son_t *  h,
const char *  name 
)

This function opens the file for reading.

Here is an example of how to read key data from a file.

1 son_t son;
2 u32 unum;
3 son_open(&son, "/home/data.son");
4 unum = son_read_unum(&son, "key.unum");
5 son_close(&son);
int son_open_array ( son_t *  h,
const char *  key 
)

Open a new array while creating or appending a SON file.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
keyThe key for the new array
Returns
Less then zero for an error
See also
son_create()
int son_open_data ( son_t *  h,
const char *  key 
)

Opens a data object for writing. The son_write_open_data() function is used to write data to the object. This function can be used when the data is not immediately availabe in RAM (for example, needs to be read from a file).

1 son_t son;
2 int fd;
3 int bytes;
4 char buffer[16];
5 
6 son_open_data(&son, "data");
7 while( (bytes = read(fd, buffer, 16)) > 0 ){
8  son_write_open_data(buffer, bytes);
9 }
10 son_close_data(&son);
Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
keyThe key for the new object
See also
son_close_data(), son_write_open_data()
int son_open_obj ( son_t *  h,
const char *  key 
)

Start a new object while creating or appending an SON file.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handle
keyThe key for the new object
Returns
Less than zero for an error (see h->err)
See also
son_create()
int son_read_bool ( son_t *  h,
const char *  key 
)

Reads the value specified by access as a boolean.

If the base data type is not true or false, it will be converted to true (1) or false (0).

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
dataA pointer to the destination data
sizeThe number of bytes available at the destination
Returns
Less than zero on an error
int son_read_data ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access,
void *  data,
son_size_t  size 
)

Reads the value specified by access as raw data (no type).

If the base data type is not raw data, it will be interpreted as raw data without performing any conversions.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
dataA pointer to the destination data
sizeThe number of bytes available at the destination
Returns
Less than zero on an error
float son_read_float ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access 
)

Reads the value specified by access as a floating point value.

If the base value is not a floating point value, it will be converted to one if possible. SON_STRING is converted using atof() and SON_DATA cannot be converted (error will be set to SON_ERR_CANNOT_CONVERT and 0.0 will be returned).

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
Returns
Less than zero on an error
s32 son_read_num ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access 
)

Reads the value specified by access as a signed integer.

If the base value is not a signed integer, it will be converted to one if possible. SON_STRING is converted using atoi() and SON_DATA cannot be converted (error will be set to SON_ERR_CANNOT_CONVERT and 0 will be returned).

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
Returns
Less than zero on an error
int son_read_str ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access,
char *  str,
son_size_t  capacity 
)

Reads the value specified by access as a string value.

If the base value is not a string, it will be converted to a string.

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
strA pointer to the destination string
capacityThe max capacity of the destination string
Returns
Less than zero on an error
u32 son_read_unum ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access 
)

Reads the value specified by access as a unsigned integer.

If the base value is not a unsigned integer, it will be converted to one if possible. SON_STRING is converted using atoi() and SON_DATA cannot be converted (error will be set to SON_ERR_CANNOT_CONVERT and 0 will be returned).

Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
Returns
Less than zero on an error
int son_seek ( son_t *  h,
const char *  access,
son_size_t *  size 
)

Seeks to the value specified by access and copies the size of the data. This function is useful if the size of the data is unknown when it needs to be read.

1 son_t s;
2 son_size_t size;
3 char * name;
4 son_open(&s, "/home/test.son");
5 
6 son_seek(&s, "person.name", &size);
7 name = malloc(size);
8 son_read_str(&s, "person.name", name, size);
Parameters
hA pointer to the handler
accessThe access string
sizeA pointer to the destination data size
Returns
Less than zero on an error

const char *  path 
)
